channel.title: Right Choice For First Coding Language?
channel.description: After holding it off for a while i started to learn a coding language. I had already learnt HTML (in like 10 minutes not really a coding language). I decided to pick C++. have many C++ books. But i decided to buy a hardback copy that came with a CD and another compiler. I picked it because I head that its good coding practice instead of visual basic or delphi. Alot of coders i know or have seen posting have said this. So i decided to pick C++. Was it a good change or will i regret it?

item.title: Right Choice For First Coding Language?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Probably already said, but Java and C++ are industry standards. C++ for applications and games, Java for virtually anything web based. They both pay well too. Java is probably the easiest to learn though, so I’d start there.

Read full topic

item.source: Right Choice For First Coding Language?

item.title: Right Choice For First Coding Language?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It’s not so much the syntax of C++ that makes it more confusing to the newcomer, it’s just that in C++ you have to worry about certain things that you don’t have to worry about in Java (pointers, knowing what’s going on with the memory, remembering to clean up after yourself). Also, the C++ standard library takes a different approach to the Java one, so Java programmings migrating to C++ will be surprised at what is(n’t) in it.

Read full topic

item.title: Right Choice For First Coding Language?
item.dc:creator: @YourDistracted YourDistracted
item.description:
@YourDistracted wrote:

The book teaches you mainly about functions, arrays, pointers and classes, But it also teaches you a whole lot more there just the main things. I don’t think it teaches any GUI in the entire book.

regecks`:

I don’t really recommend picking up C++ unless you’re looking to do it very seriously. (Or you want to write various hacks :P)

I am looking into doing it seriously depending on how good I do after this book. If I understand I will go further. And do some serious programming.

Read full topic
item.source: Right Choice For First Coding Language?

item.title: Right Choice For First Coding Language?

item.description:
@Taios wrote:

Attempt a few things. Decide what works best for you. Everyone is different

Read full topic
item.source: Right Choice For First Coding Language?

item.title: Right Choice For First Coding Language?
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

Books that have whole sections dedicated to GUI are silly.
The book should be about the actual language and its concepts rather than teaching some parts of the languages’ API. Languages are really very simple once you have the general concept down, I dun see why so many books like concentrating on specific crap such as GUI coding when it really had little to do with the language (o gawdz VB coderz).

I picked it because I head that its good coding practice instead of visual basic or delphi.
Forces good coding practice*. It also lets you be very very slack, depending which way you look at it.

I don’t really recommend picking up C++ unless you’re looking to do it very seriously. (Or you want to write various hacks :P)

Read full topic
item.source: Right Choice For First Coding Language?
